Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the increase in average family premiums under Obama by stating it as 29% without providing the context of the time period and comparison to previous years.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it does not provide any evidence or data to back up the statement.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the increase in average family premiums under Obama is solely attributable to his policies, without considering other factors that may have contributed to the increase.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not consider alternative explanations for the increase in average family premiums, such as changes in healthcare costs or inflation rates.
Falters at times: The claim falters by not providing a comprehensive analysis of the increase in average family premiums and only focusing on a specific time period.
Understate: The claim may understate the rate of increase in average family premiums by not considering the higher rate of increase in previous years.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that premiums actually increased less quickly under Obama compared to the period between 1999 and 2008.
